review.title: Basic Formal Properties of A Relational Model of The Mathematical Theory of Evidence
review.abstract: The paper presents a novel view of the Dempster-Shafer belief function as a measure of diversity in relational data bases. It is demonstrated that under the interpretation The Dempster rule of evidence combination corresponds to the join operator of the relational database theory. This rough-set based interpretation is qualitative in nature and can represent a number of belief function operators.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 4.02 468v 1 [cs.A I] 8 AThe paper presents a new view of the Dempster-Shafer belief function as a measure of diversity in relational databases. The Dempster rule of evidence combination corresponds to the join operator of relational database theory. This rough interpretation is of a qualitative nature and can represent a number of faith function operators. 1

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before agreement is reached.

sections.heading: 2 Basics of the Dempster-Shafer Theory
sections.text: We understand MTE in a very traditional way (see [13]). Let us be a finite set of elementary events called elementary events. Each subset of A is a composite event or hypothesis.

sections.heading: 3 Rough Set Theory. The Traditional Interpreta-
4 New Interpretation
sections.text: Below, we present a slight modification of the rough interpretation of belief functions, which surprisingly turn out to be both simple and elegant and simple, while at the same time meeting the requirement that does not agree with known interpretations: it is qualitative and not quantitative in nature and yet case-by-case. Furthermore, we show that our new interpretation strictly corresponds to the concept of multivalued dependence, i.e. the combination of belief experiments that we have and 43 tails, then this is a quantitative evaluation from the database. But when we say that there were heads and tails (and not tails), then we say something about the qualitative aspects of the experiment. In the quantitative evaluation, we say that 57% of all cases we had heads and tails that we were not qualitative.

sections.heading: 4.1 Conditioning as Selection of a Subtable
sections.text: BelTAB (. | | B) defines the BelTAB (. | | B) conditionality function, which defines BelTAB B (.) as the BelTAB (.) faith function based on evidence B. It is easy to see that PlBUILD ([[Restaurant]] | | School, Restaurant}) = 2 / 3 (PTS Ltd., ZZZ Ltd.) and mBUILD ([Restaurant] | School, Restaurant}) = 1 / 3 (PTS Ltd.).Our conditionality function fits perfectly with the above definition of Bel (. | | B).

sections.heading: 4.2 Combination as Relational Join
sections.text: We want to combine independent evidence from both tables to support a decision. Let us assume that the independence of evidence means that no pair of companies (one of BUILD, one of EQUIP) refuses to cooperate in the construction and furnishing of an object. How many pairs of companies do we need to complete a series of objects mentioned in the offers? The answers in the relation table FINISH (one of BUILD, one of EQUIP) receive as a relative accession of BUILD and EQUIP (via the joint column D) so that the new decision table 

sections.heading: 4.3 Relational Marginalization and Decombination
sections.text: Another aspect that is not present in any interpretation of MTE is the relationship between relational marginalization and MTE factorization ("decombination") of faith functions. Example 5 Note that in our example, BUILD and EQUIP are identical both in the first normal form and in the domain of the attribute D. Therefore, we know of elementary properties of relational data tables, the marginalization of FINISH via I, Dselect I, D of FINISH; is exactly identical to BUILD. and the marginalization of FINISH via I2, Dselect distinct I2, D of FINISH; is exactly identical to EQUIP. Generally: Theorem 4 If the information part I of the decision table DT (I, D) can be divided into two such parts.

sections.heading: 4.4 Multivariate Beliefs and Multidecision Tables
sections.text: It is trivial to see that dropping a decision variable does not reduce the diversity of the information part. In our search for non-quantitative interpretation of MTE, our attention was attracted by the nature of the join operator of relational databases [1] or in general the multivalued dependency [2] the study of which led to invention of local computation method for uncertainty propagation of Shenoy and Shafer [20] for MTE.

Throughout the paper, as relational data tables are subject of rough set theory, SQL [26] query language is used to express semantics of MTE measures and operators in terms of decision tables, both with respect to traditional and our rough sets based interpretation of MTE, as SQL has the capability of expressing purely relational and frequentistic data processing.

Skowron and Grzyma la-Busse[23] elaborated a procedure consisting in transforming the combined decision tables into a kind of summary with multivalued decision columns (since non-relational) and then applying complex rational arithmetic to get finally a decision table (derived by so-called Ψ-independent combination) implementing Dempster combination of independent belief functions (consult [23] for details).

In the ”probability of provability” approach [11] not a probability of correctness, but rather the number of distinct valid proofs of a statement should be counted.
In the ”possible world semantics” [15] the worlds should not be assigned a probability, but rather distinct possible worlds should be counted that differ in non-essential details.

metadata.abstractText: The paper presents a novel view of the Dempster-Shafer belief function as a measure of diversity in relational data bases. The Dempster rule of evidence combination corresponds to the join operator of the relational database theory. This rough-set based interpretation is qualitative in nature and can represent a number of belief function operators.
